The strange thing about the retina is that it's inverted.

The photoreceptor cells that I just mentioned, which are there to receive the light, actually are not on top of the retina where you would expect them, so close to the lens, but they're actually on the far side - which means that all the light has to propagate through the entire retina before it can be received by the photoreceptor cells.
Which seems to be a very strange arrangement, because that means that any image that's under the retina can potentially be scattered, distorted, and the image quality deteriorates.
And that's been a puzzle for a very long time, why the retina is inverted and why we still see clear images.
I mean, that situation amounts to putting a sun diffusing screen in front of your photograph film or CCD chip in your camera and then expecting that you can get clean images.
Mm-hmm.
So, that's the general problem that you have to deal with in this situation.

So, what we published a few years back, actually was - that there are some cells in the retina called Muller glial cells, which are long cylindrical and have a high receptive index, and they work just like optical fibers they use for telecommunications, for example, that kind of channel the light almost all the way down through the retina.
Like a tube.
They go like on a tube, then, to the back of the retina.

…to the back of the retina, yeah.

It's not as black and white, but they have to get light, basically, almost all the way down to the retina, to the photoreceptor cells.
And that seems to take care of most of the problem, especially in diurnal animals such as ourselves.
The nocturnal animals are different because they want to see at very low light levels, which means they need to have very high sensitivity.
And they do that by having a lot of rod photoreceptor cells.
So many of them - which means that there are also many nuclei to these photoreceptor cells.
